page.title: 03LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: The Alverbank Hotel is the site of a former brickworks,the access to which was on the Stokes Bay Road. Crossing the bridge over the River Alver at low tide you can still see some supports of the pier belonging to the brickworks. From here bricks were shipped and coal landed in the l820's. Behind the course of the old moat are parts of the ramparts and in some gardens you can see evidence of narrow entrenchments, dug for the defence of this part of the coast. On the right side of Jellicoe Avenue there is still a high stone wall. This formed the boundary of Alvercliff house,a former residence of the Commander of the Royal Engineers.The house was built on the site of the Stokes Bay Battery no2 Redoubt.
